post: Did you know you can use a Donor Advised Fund (DAF) to support civic and history education? A DAF is a flexible, tax-advantaged way to give back, allowing you to make charitable contributions and recommend grants over time. By directing your DAF to the Bill of Rights Institute, you can help empower students and educators with free resources to explore the founding principles of our nation. Make an impact today! Visit supportbri.org to learn more about how your generosity can shape the future of civic education.  #BillofRightsInstitute  #BRI  #DAFs

Civics education is an opportunity to nurture empathy, respect, and inclusion in the classroom,  says Bridget Jordan, BRI Teacher Fellow. Growing up, Bridget dreamed of becoming a brain surgeon, but her true calling emerged when she discovered her passion for working with children. Now, as an ESOL teacher at Baltimore Highlands Elementary, Bridget is empowering her multilingual students to connect with civics and history in meaningful ways. Through BRI's Teacher Fellowship, Bridget has transformed her teaching strategies to make civics accessible for diverse learners. Read more about her story, here  https://lnkd.in/efd9PJwN.  #BillofRightsInstitute  #BRI  #teacherfellowship

BRI is excited to announce our newest affiliate partnership with History By Mail. History By Mail is a monthly subscription service for reproductions of historical letters and documents. Each replica comes with a separate document explaining the context of the letter, including its author, recipient, and relevance to the events of its time, as well as a transcription when necessary. Use code 'BRI' to receive a discount at checkout. A portion of your purchase will support BRI, helping us provide free civics and history education to classrooms nationwide.  https://lnkd.in/eNRSQW2C  #BillofRightsInstitute  #BRI  #affiliate

How do the federal, state, and local governments share power? In our lesson "Which Level of Government Can Solve This Problem?" from our newest Core resource, Government and Politics: Civics for the American Experiment, students explore the dynamic balance of federalism and analyze real-world scenarios to understand how government functions at every level. Dive in today,  https://lnkd.in/erq23zvA

"My goal as a history teacher has always been to help students make meaningful connections to the past, to each other, and to the ideas that shape our world," says Elizabeth Summerlin, a Gary Colletti Conference Scholarship recipient and teacher at Mill Creek High School, GA. With support from the Bill of Rights Institute, Elizabeth attended the National Council for the Social Studies conference for the first time. From insights on leadership to sessions on grassroots movements and civic simulations, she gained invaluable tools to bring history to life for her students. Elizabeth shared, "BRIs dedication to civic education aligns perfectly with my classroom goals, helping students build connections that will shape their future."
